        <!---->
        
      </div><br>
    
        
      
        I would also guess that fixing this in Chromium would fix it in Edge.<span class="line"><!---->I would also guess that fixing this in Chromium would fix it in Edge.<!----></span><br><br>This is pretty interesting. I think the callpath is NavigationURLLoaderImpl::PrepareForNonInterceptedRequest() -> ChromeContentBrowserClient::HandleExternalProtocol(). In the former, we pass what eventually ends up in the dialog as ResourceRequest::request_initiator:<span class="line"><!---->This is pretty interesting. I think the callpath is NavigationURLLoaderImpl::PrepareForNonInterceptedRequest() -&gt; ChromeContentBrowserClient::HandleExternalProtocol(). In the former, we pass what eventually ends up in the dialog as ResourceRequest::request_initiator:<!----></span><br><br>      bool handled = GetContentClient()->browser()->HandleExternalProtocol(<span class="line"><!---->      bool handled = GetContentClient()-&gt;browser()-&gt;HandleExternalProtocol(<!----></span><br>          resource_request_->url, web_contents_getter_,<span class="line"><!---->          resource_request_-&gt;url, web_contents_getter_,<!----></span><br>          ChildProcessHost::kInvalidUniqueID, frame_tree_node_id_,<span class="line"><!---->          ChildProcessHost::kInvalidUniqueID, frame_tree_node_id_,<!----></span><br>          navigation_ui_data_.get(),<span class="line"><!---->          navigation_ui_data_.get(),<!----></span><br>          resource_request_->resource_type ==<span class="line"><!---->          resource_request_-&gt;resource_type ==<!----></span><br>              static_cast<int>(blink::mojom::ResourceType::kMainFrame),<span class="line"><!---->              static_cast&lt;int&gt;(blink::mojom::ResourceType::kMainFrame),<!----></span><br>          static_cast<ui::PageTransition>(resource_request_->transition_type),<span class="line"><!---->          static_cast&lt;ui::PageTransition&gt;(resource_request_-&gt;transition_type),<!----></span><br>          resource_request_->has_user_gesture,<span class="line"><!---->          resource_request_-&gt;has_user_gesture,<!----></span><br>          /* this is what ends up in the dialog -> */ resource_request_->request_initiator,<span class="line"><!---->          /* this is what ends up in the dialog -&gt; */ resource_request_-&gt;request_initiator,<!----></span><br>          &loader_factory);<span class="line"><!---->          &amp;loader_factory);<!----></span><br><br>I'm guessing that on a server side redirect, the initiator is still the origin from whence the navigation came. It would be odd if the omnibox origin didn't match.<span class="line"><!---->At the very least, the origin in the omnibox matches the origin in the dialog in the top frame examples, which makes me suspect that this may actually be working as intended.         To expand on my <span class="line"><!---->To expand on my <!----></span>comment #7<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c7"><!---->comment #7<!----></a>, what I'm wondering is whether navigating to a URL which performs an immediate server-side redirect to an external protocol is effectively the same as the original site having a link directly embedding that external protocol.         To clarify my comment, HTTP Auth *does* seem to commit navigation. What I meant was that external protocol handling seems similar to HTTP Auth in terms of behavior trigger (response header controls behavior) and user flow (sensitive dialog with origin info), therefore external protocol handling probably should look more like HTTP Auth flow which commits and shows origin of dialog initiator (server sending the triggering response headers).<span class="line"><!---->To clarify my comment, HTTP Auth *does* seem to commit navigation. What I meant was that external protocol handling seems similar to HTTP Auth in terms of behavior trigger (response header controls behavior) and user flow (sensitive dialog with origin info), therefore external protocol handling probably should look more like HTTP Auth flow which commits and shows origin of dialog initiator (server sending the triggering response headers).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        This looks like a variant of <span class="line"><!---->This looks like a variant of <!----></span>bug 1091961<span class="line"><!---->bug 1091961<!----></span>: The navigation doesn't update content area but ends up showing some non-content area dialog, causing a mismatch between the omnibox and the dialog.<span class="line"><!---->: The navigation doesn't update content area but ends up showing some non-content area dialog, causing a mismatch between the omnibox and the dialog.<!----></span><br><br>We have many of these. Basically, anytime a navigation results in a UI (dialog, download shelf, external app opening etc) that doesn't update the omnibox, we'll have this issue. The similarity to the HTTP auth case is a great observation, and we might need to do something similar here as well.<span class="line"><!---->We have many of these. Basically, anytime a navigation results in a UI (dialog, download shelf, external app opening etc) that doesn't update the omnibox, we'll have this issue. The similarity to the HTTP auth case is a great observation, and we might need to do something similar here as well.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for context. Don't have access to crbug with impact details of variants in other features, but for this feature, impact seems particularly dangerous beyond origin spoof in dialog:<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for context. Don't have access to crbug with impact details of variants in other features, but for this feature, impact seems particularly dangerous beyond origin spoof in dialog:<!----></span><br><br>1. An open redirect in an allowlisted origin can launch the protocol with zero interaction<span class="line"><!---->1. An open redirect in an allowlisted origin can launch the protocol with zero interaction<!----></span><br>e.g. Video conferencing site has open redirect + large % of userbase has origin+protocol allowlisted due to frequent use/enterprise policy + app has RCE vuln or other vuln via protocol handler<span class="line"><!---->e.g. Video conferencing site has open redirect + large % of userbase has origin+protocol allowlisted due to frequent use/enterprise policy + app has RCE vuln or other vuln via protocol handler<!----></span><br><br>2. Reasonably sandboxed iframe embedded by allowlisted origin can launch the protocol with zero interaction<span class="line"><!---->2. Reasonably sandboxed iframe embedded by allowlisted origin can launch the protocol with zero interaction<!----></span><br>e.g. Video conferencing site embeds 3rd party/arbitrary sandboxed iframe + user/enterprise has origin+protocol allowlisted + app has vuln via protocol handler<span class="line"><!---->e.g. Video conferencing site embeds 3rd party/arbitrary sandboxed iframe + user/enterprise has origin+protocol allowlisted + app has vuln via protocol handler<!----></span><br><br>3. Any link within allowlisted origin can launch protocol if clicked<span class="line"><!---->3. Any link within allowlisted origin can launch protocol if clicked<!----></span><br>e.g. Video conferencing site allows user-controlled HTTPS links in event descriptions, profile info, etc. + user/enterprise has origin+protocol allowlisted + app has vuln via protocol handler<span class="line"><!---->e.g. Video conferencing site allows user-controlled HTTPS links in event descriptions, profile info, etc. + user/enterprise has origin+protocol allowlisted + app has vuln via protocol handler<!----></span><br><br>If not allowlisted, only a single click in dialog is needed and it appears to be from the user-trusted website, so it's likely to be effective. There's also very few (if any) mitigations that I could find: CSP and sandboxing are largely ineffective; most websites with some type of user content allow user-controlled HTTPS links; combined with <span class="line"><!---->If not allowlisted, only a single click in dialog is needed and it appears to be from the user-trusted website, so it's likely to be effective. There's also very few (if any) mitigations that I could find: CSP and sandboxing are largely ineffective; most websites with some type of user content allow user-controlled HTTPS links; combined with <!----></span>issue 1196495<span class="line"><!---->issue 1196495<!----></span> and<span class="line"><!----> and<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>issue 1096610<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1096610" title="External Protocol handler anti-flood protection is ineffective and flaky"><!---->issue 1096610<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>behaviors, it's easy to bypass protocol launch user interaction requirements for many users.<span class="line"><!---->behaviors, it's easy to bypass protocol launch user interaction requirements for many users.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">

        Sorry for the delay.         Re: <span class="line"><!---->Re: <!----></span>#c19<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c19"><!---->#c19<!----></a>, that's correct, passing origin of last redirecting server should take care of dialog origin spoof in all reported scenarios.<span class="line"><!---->, that's correct, passing origin of last redirecting server should take care of dialog origin spoof in all reported scenarios.<!----></span><br><br>There's still other apparent issues, such as sandbox + CSP bypass and omnibox mismatch, but those would be moot if server-side redirect is blocked altogether (thanks for filing spinoff <span class="line"><!---->There's still other apparent issues, such as sandbox + CSP bypass and omnibox mismatch, but those would be moot if server-side redirect is blocked altogether (thanks for filing spinoff <!----></span>issue 1203814<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1203814" title="Consider blocking HTTP -> externally-handled-protocol redirects "><!---->issue 1203814<!----></a>).<span class="line"><!---->).<!----></span><br><br>> <span class="line"><!---->&gt; <!----></span>#c19<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c19"><!---->#c19<!----></a>: I would expect the correct origin to be shown in the dialog here [here = in absence of http redirects]).<span class="line"><!---->: I would expect the correct origin to be shown in the dialog here [here = in absence of http redirects]).<!----></span><br><br>Yes, current behavior is safe for direct navigation scenarios (e.g. <a href="ms-calculator:">calc</a> or window.location = 'ms-calculator:'). The current page's origin is shown as expected. I would expect direct navigation to still be allowed, since untrusted non-HTTPS URLs can and should be blocked by websites, much like they often block direct javascript: URLs in anchor href, window.location, window.open, iframe src, etc.<span class="line"><!---->Yes, current behavior is safe for direct navigation scenarios (e.g. &lt;a href="ms-calculator:"&gt;calc&lt;/a&gt; or window.location = 'ms-calculator:'). The current page's origin is shown as expected. I would expect direct navigation to still be allowed, since untrusted non-HTTPS URLs can and should be blocked by websites, much like they often block direct javascript: URLs in anchor href, window.location, window.open, iframe src, etc.<!----></span><br><br>Scenario 2 is for window.location navigation to a URL which returns a server-side redirect. Under the hood it's essentially the same behavior, but wanted to make it clear this repros with other common places where untrusted URLs are accepted by websites. (For reference, Scenario 2 PoC: <span class="line"><!---->Scenario 2 is for window.location navigation to a URL which returns a server-side redirect. Under the hood it's essentially the same behavior, but wanted to make it clear this repros with other common places where untrusted URLs are accepted by websites. (For reference, Scenario 2 PoC: <!----></span>https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Faogarantiza.com%2Fchromium%2Fexternal-protocol%2Fcalc.php&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AFQjCNGOqAoEa7AghaevcuD3T2XmJY62gw<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Faogarantiza.com%2Fchromium%2Fexternal-protocol%2Fcalc.php&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNGOqAoEa7AghaevcuD3T2XmJY62gw"><!---->https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Faogarantiza.com%2Fchromium%2Fexternal-protocol%2Fcalc.php&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNGOqAoEa7AghaevcuD3T2XmJY62gw<!----></a> )<span class="line"><!----> )<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        meacer: Uh oh! This issue still open and hasn't been updated in the last 14 days. This is a serious vulnerability, and we want to ensure that there's progress.         ravjit@: The patch at <span class="line"><!---->ravjit@: The patch at <!----></span>https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/3113931<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/3113931"><!---->https://chromium-review.googlesource.com/c/chromium/src/+/3113931<!----></a> LGTM. I see there's still some outstanding comments regarding the tests; hope those are resolved soon so the fix can make it to users sooner than later.<span class="line"><!----> LGTM. I see there's still some outstanding comments regarding the tests; hope those are resolved soon so the fix can make it to users sooner than later.<!----></span><br><br>The Firefox team was waiting on the Chromium team to decide on mitigation strategy. Now that the strategy is settled, I've left a comment in <span class="line"><!---->The Firefox team was waiting on the Chromium team to decide on mitigation strategy. Now that the strategy is settled, I've left a comment in <!----></span>https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1705211#c15<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1705211#c15"><!---->https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1705211#c15<!----></a> to see if they're ready to implement similar fix or if they have any concerns. (Not sure if there's already been comms not documented in either bug tracker.)<span class="line"><!----> to see if they're ready to implement similar fix or if they have any concerns. (Not sure if there's already been comms not documented in either bug tracker.)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        The following revision refers to this bug:<span class="line"><!---->The following revision refers to this bug:<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/f781748dcb3c7d0420b884c1c24b9b4497bc7c97<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/f781748dcb3c7d0420b884c1c24b9b4497bc7c97"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/f781748dcb3c7d0420b884c1c24b9b4497bc7c97<!----></a><br><br>commit <span class="line"><!---->commit <!----></span>f781748dcb3c7d0420b884c1c24b9b4497bc7c97<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/f781748dcb3c7d0420b884c1c24b9b4497bc7c97"><!---->f781748dcb3c7d0420b884c1c24b9b4497bc7c97<!----></a><br>Author: Ravjit <<span class="line"><!---->Author: Ravjit &lt;<!----></span>ravjit@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/ravjit@chromium.org"><!---->ravjit@chromium.org<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><br>Date: Thu Sep 16 12:29:55 2021<span class="line"><!---->Date: Thu Sep 16 12:29:55 2021<!----></span><br><br>Show the origin of the last redirecting server in external protocol handler dialogs<span class="line"><!---->Show the origin of the last redirecting server in external protocol handler dialogs<!----></span><br><br>External protocol handlers always show the initiating url's origin. This can be misleading if there are server side redirects.<span class="line"><!---->External protocol handlers always show the initiating url's origin. This can be misleading if there are server side redirects.<!----></span><br>Now we will show the origin of the last redirecting server (falling back to the request_initiator if there were no redirects / if the request goes straight to an external protocol).<span class="line"><!---->Now we will show the origin of the last redirecting server (falling back to the request_initiator if there were no redirects / if the request goes straight to an external protocol).<!----></span><br><br>Bug: 1197889<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1197889"         *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Description #1 by alesa...@alesandroortiz.com (Apr 10, 2021)

        Description #1 by alesa...@alesandroortiz.com (Apr 10, 2021)

        </select>

      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>A URL responding with a server-side redirect to an external protocol can trigger an external protocol dialog with a spoofed origin. The origin is never the redirecting URL's origin. Instead, the initiating page's origin (or precursor origin if opaque) is shown in dialogs. This affects both application protocols (e.g. ms-calculator:) and the telephone protocol (tel:). The UI for these are different, but the effects are similar in most cases.<span class="line"><!---->A URL responding with a server-side redirect to an external protocol can trigger an external protocol dialog with a spoofed origin. The origin is never the redirecting URL's origin. Instead, the initiating page's origin (or precursor origin if opaque) is shown in dialogs. This affects both application protocols (e.g. ms-calculator:) and the telephone protocol (tel:). The UI for these are different, but the effects are similar in most cases.<!----></span><br><br>For example, if a page on <span class="line"><!---->For example, if a page on <!----></span>https://www.google[.]com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.google[.]com"><!---->https://www.google[.]com<!----></a> contains a link (<a href="...">) to <span class="line"><!----> contains a link (&lt;a href="..."&gt;) to <!----></span>https://attacker[.]tld/redirect<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://attacker[.]tld/redirect"><!---->https://attacker[.]tld/redirect<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> and a user clicks the link, the dialog will show <span class="line"><!----> and a user clicks the link, the dialog will show <!----></span>https://www.google[.]com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.google[.]com"><!---->https://www.google[.]com<!----></a> as the origin instead of <span class="line"><!----> as the origin instead of <!----></span>https://attacker[.]tld<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://attacker[.]tld"><!---->https://attacker[.]tld<!----></a> .<span class="line"><!----> .<!----></span><br><br>Similarly, if a page on <span class="line"><!---->Similarly, if a page on <!----></span>https://www.google[.]com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.google[.]com"><!---->https://www.google[.]com<!----></a> navigates the current window or new window via JavaScript (window.location or window.open()) to <span class="line"><!----> navigates the current window or new window via JavaScript (window.location or window.open()) to <!----></span>https://attacker[.]tld/redirect<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://attacker[.]tld/redirect"><!---->https://attacker[.]tld/redirect<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> the dialog will show <span class="line"><!----> the dialog will show <!----></span>https://www.google[.]com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.google[.]com"><!---->https://www.google[.]com<!----></a> as the origin.<span class="line"><!----> as the origin.<!----></span><br><br>In effect, the behavior is the same as if the page had directly used the external protocol URL (ms-calculator:) instead of the HTTPS URL (<span class="line"><!---->In effect, the behavior is the same as if the page had directly used the external protocol URL (ms-calculator:) instead of the HTTPS URL (<!----></span>https://attacker[.]tld/redirect<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://attacker[.]tld/redirect"><!---->https://attacker[.]tld/redirect<!----></a>).<span class="line"><!---->).<!----></span><br><br>As far as I can tell, common protections such as CSP and iframe sandboxing are bypassed in most scenarios.<span class="line"><!---->As far as I can tell, common protections such as CSP and iframe sandboxing are bypassed in most scenarios.<!----></span><br><br>No user interaction is needed if a user previously checked "Always allow {origin} to open links of this type..." for the target origin and protocol, or if allowed for origin+protocol via enterprise policy: <span class="line"><!---->No user interaction is needed if a user previously checked "Always allow {origin} to open links of this type..." for the target origin and protocol, or if allowed for origin+protocol via enterprise policy: <!----></span>https://chromeenterprise.google/policies/#AutoLaunchProtocolsFromOrigins<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromeenterprise.google/policies/#AutoLaunchProtocolsFromOrigins"><!---->https://chromeenterprise.google/policies/#AutoLaunchProtocolsFromOrigins<!----></a><br><br>ADDITIONAL INFO<span class="line"><!---->ADDITIONAL INFO<!----></span><br>A malicious URL could be placed in search result pages, "external link" interstitial pages, user-provided URLs in content, among many other scenarios. Most websites filter input to only allow http(s) URLs (generally to avoid javascript: URLs which are blocked by browser in server-side redirects), therefore this works as an effective bypass to spoof the origin across most websites and navigation methods.<span class="line"><!---->A malicious URL could be placed in search result pages, "external link" interstitial pages, user-provided URLs in content, among many other scenarios. Most websites filter input to only allow http(s) URLs (generally to avoid javascript: URLs which are blocked by browser in server-side redirects), therefore this works as an effective bypass to spoof the origin across most websites and navigation methods.<!----></span><br><br>See attached video spoof-google-search.mp4 for Google Search demo with both calc and tel PoCs. Note that I only enabled this PoC to work from my IP address for a few minutes to record the video.<span class="line"><!---->See attached video spoof-google-search.mp4 for Google Search demo with both calc and tel PoCs. Note that I only enabled this PoC to work from my IP address for a few minutes to record the video.<!----></span><br><br>External protocols in server-side redirects probably should be treated similarly to javascript: URLs in server-side redirects, which are blocked by the browser as unsafe. Otherwise, the browser could render a blank page with origin set to the server-side redirect initiator, to ensure the dialog and address bar show the correct origin and the tab doesn't have another origin's content rendered.<span class="line"><!---->External protocols in server-side redirects probably should be treated similarly to javascript: URLs in server-side redirects, which are blocked by the browser as unsafe. Otherwise, the browser could render a blank page with origin set to the server-side redirect initiator, to ensure the dialog and address bar show the correct origin and the tab doesn't have another origin's content rendered.<!----></span><br><br>Some of the PoCs benefit from behaviors described in <span class="line"><!---->Some of the PoCs benefit from behaviors described in <!----></span>issue 1196495<span class="line"><!---->issue 1196495<!----></span> and<span class="line"><!----> and<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>issue 1096610<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1096610" title="External Protocol handler anti-flood protection is ineffective and flaky"><!---->issue 1096610<!----></a>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>but are not dependent on them for success.<span class="line"><!---->but are not dependent on them for success.<!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 89.0.4389.114 (Official Build) (64-bit) (cohort: Stable), also repros on 91.0.4468.0 Canary<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 89.0.4389.114 (Official Build) (64-bit) (cohort: Stable), also repros on 91.0.4468.0 Canary<!----></span><br>Operating System: Windows 10 OS Version 2009 (Build 19042.867)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Windows 10 OS Version 2009 (Build 19042.867)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>Scenario 1: Link click<span class="line"><!---->Scenario 1: Link click<!----></span><br>1. Navigate to <span class="line"><!---->1. Navigate to <!----></span>https://alesandroortiz.com/security/chromium/external-protocol/spoof-links.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://alesandroortiz.com/security/chromium/external-protocol/spoof-links.html"><!---->https://alesandroortiz.com/security/chromium/external-protocol/spoof-links.html<!----></a><br>2. Click either of the links<span class="line"><!---->2. Click either of the links<!----></span><br><br>Observed: External protocol dialog shown with current page origin (<span class="line"><!---->Observed: External protocol dialog shown with current page origin (<!----></span>https://alesandroortiz[.]com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://alesandroortiz[.]com"><!---->https://alesandroortiz[.]com<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><br>Expected: External protocol dialog is not shown or is shown with redirecting origin (<span class="line"><!---->Expected: External protocol dialog is not shown or is shown with redirecting origin (<!----></span>https://aogarantiza[.]com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://aogarantiza[.]com"><!---->https://aogarantiza[.]com<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><br><br>Scenario 2: JavaScript redirect (window.location)<span class="line"><!---->Scenario 2: JavaScript redirect (window.location)<!----></span><br>1. Navigate to one of these URLs:<span class="line"><!---->1. Navigate to one of these URLs:<!----></span><br>https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Faogarantiza.com%2Fchromium%2Fexternal-protocol%2Fcalc.php&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AFQjCNGOqAoEa7AghaevcuD3T2XmJY62gw<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Faogarantiza.com%2Fchromium%2Fexternal-protocol%2Fcalc.php&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNGOqAoEa7AghaevcuD3T2XmJY62gw"><!---->https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Faogarantiza.com%2Fchromium%2Fexternal-protocol%2Fcalc.php&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNGOqAoEa7AghaevcuD3T2XmJY62gw<!----></a><br>https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Faogarantiza.com%2Fchromium%2Fexternal-protocol%2Ftel.php&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AFQjCNEUEKsWLeTxzL6gKZT1TR_zarnCJg<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Faogarantiza.com%2Fchromium%2Fexternal-protocol%2Ftel.php&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNEUEKsWLeTxzL6gKZT1TR_zarnCJg"><!---->https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Faogarantiza.com%2Fchromium%2Fexternal-protocol%2Ftel.php&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNEUEKsWLeTxzL6gKZT1TR_zarnCJg<!----></a><br><br>Observed: Dialog shown with correct origin.<span class="line"><!---->Observed: Dialog shown with correct origin.<!----></span><br>Expected: Dialog shown with spoofed origin.<span class="line"><!---->Expected: Dialog shown with spoofed origin.<!----></span><br><br>Scenario 3: Page has iframe with user-controlled src to URL responding with server-side redirect<span class="line"><!---->Scenario 3: Page has iframe with user-controlled src to URL responding with server-side redirect<!----></span><br>1. Navigate to <span class="line"><!---->1. Navigate to <!----></span>https://alesandroortiz.com/security/chromium/external-protocol/spoof-iframe-sandbox-calc.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://alesandroortiz.com/security/chromium/external-protocol/spoof-iframe-sandbox-calc.html"><!---->https://alesandroortiz.com/security/chromium/external-protocol/spoof-iframe-sandbox-calc.html<!----></a><br><br>Observed: Dialog shown with embedding page origin (<span class="line"><!---->Observed: Dialog shown with embedding page origin (<!----></span>https://alesandroortiz[.]com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://alesandroortiz[.]com"><!---->https://alesandroortiz[.]com<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><br>Expected: Dialog shown with iframe src origin (<span class="line"><!---->Expected: Dialog shown with iframe src origin (<!----></span>https://aogarantiza[.]com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://aogarantiza[.]com"><!---->https://aogarantiza[.]com<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><br><br>Scenario 4: Page with iframe srcdoc (sandboxed)<span class="line"><!---->Scenario 4: Page with iframe srcdoc (sandboxed)<!----></span><br>1. Navigate to <span class="line"><!---->1. Navigate to <!----></span>https://alesandroortiz.com/security/chromium/external-protocol/spoof-iframe-srcdoc-calc.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://alesandroortiz.com/security/chromium/external-protocol/spoof-iframe-srcdoc-calc.html"><!---->https://alesandroortiz.com/security/chromium/external-protocol/spoof-iframe-srcdoc-calc.html<!----></a><br>2. Observe onload PoC of second iframe, then click link in first iframe<span class="line"><!---->2. Observe onload PoC of second iframe, then click link in first iframe<!----></span><br><br>Observed: Dialog shown with embedding page origin (<span class="line"><!---->Observed: Dialog shown with embedding page origin (<!----></span>https://alesandroortiz[.]com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://alesandroortiz[.]com"><!---->https://alesandroortiz[.]com<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><br>Expected: Dialog shown with iframe src origin (<span class="line"><!---->Expected: Dialog shown with iframe src origin (<!----></span>https://aogarantiza[.]com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://aogarantiza[.]com"><!---->https://aogarantiza[.]com<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><br><br>Scenario 5: Attacker page with refreshing iframe with client-side redirect leading to server-side redirect<span class="line"><!---->Scenario 5: Attacker page with refreshing iframe with client-side redirect leading to server-side redirect<!----></span><br>1. Navigate to <span class="line"><!---->1. Navigate to <!----></span>https://alesandroortiz.com/security/chromium/external-protocol/spoof-iframe-src-calc.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://alesandroortiz.com/security/chromium/external-protocol/spoof-iframe-src-calc.html"><!---->https://alesandroortiz.com/security/chromium/external-protocol/spoof-iframe-src-calc.html<!----></a><br>2. With most extensions, prompt will be reshown without further user interactions (<span class="line"><!---->2. With most extensions, prompt will be reshown without further user interactions (<!----></span>issue 173557<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=173557" title="Security: Extensions can enable websites to carpet bomb with external protocol dialogs"><!---->issue 173557<!----></a>). Otherwise, interact with any page or browser UI to show prompt.<span class="line"><!---->). Otherwise, interact with any page or browser UI to show prompt.<!----></span><br><br>Observed: Dialog shown with embedding page origin (<span class="line"><!---->Observed: Dialog shown with embedding page origin (<!----></span>https://alesandroortiz[.]com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://alesandroortiz[.]com"><!---->https://alesandroortiz[.]com<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><br>Expected: Dialog shown with iframe src origin (<span class="line"><!---->Expected: Dialog shown with iframe src origin (<!----></span>https://aogarantiza[.]com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://aogarantiza[.]com"><!---->https://aogarantiza[.]com<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><br><br>Other scenarios in PoCs below.<span class="line"><!---->Other scenarios in PoCs below.<!----></span><br><br>You can re-test any of the app protocol PoCs after checking "Always allow..." to verify the app will be launched without interaction if previously allowed.<span class="line"><!---->You can re-test any of the app protocol PoCs after checking "Always allow..." to verify the app will be launched without interaction if previously allowed.<!----></span><br><br>ALL PROOF OF CONCEPTS<span class="line"><!---->ALL PROOF OF CONCEPTS<!----></span><br>App protocols and tel: protocols:<span class="line"><!---->App protocols and tel: protocols:<!----></span><br>https://alesandroortiz.com/security/chromium/external-protocol/spoof-links.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://alesandroortiz.com/security/chromium/external-protocol/spoof-links.html"><!---->https://alesandroortiz.com/security/chromium/external-protocol/spoof-links.html<!----></a><br><br>App protocols:<span class="line"><!---->App protocols:<!----></span><br>https://alesandroortiz.com/security/chromium/external-protocol/spoof-iframe-sandbox-calc.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" protocols, misc:<span class="line"><!---->App protocols, misc:<!----></span><br>https://alesandroortiz.com/security/chromium/external-protocol/spoof-new-tab.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" external link demo, user click (equivalent to spoof-links.html PoC):<span class="line"><!---->Google external link demo, user click (equivalent to spoof-links.html ~open client-side redirect demo, window.location (used in iframe PoCs to spoof Google origin):<span class="line"><!---->Google ~open client-side redirect demo, window.location (used in iframe PoCs to automatic Google redirect links were created by creating links in Google Sites: <span class="line"><!---->The automatic Google redirect links were created by creating links in Google Sites: <!----></span>https://sites.google.com/view/aortest1/external-protocol-poc-1<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://sites.google.com/view/aortest1/external-protocol-poc-1"><!---->https://sites.google.com/view/aortest1/external-protocol-poc-1<!----></a><br><br>Source for HTML files attached. Source for server-side redirect URLs below:<span class="line"><!---->Source for HTML files attached. Source for server-side redirect URLs below:<!----></span><br>calc.php: <?php header('Location: ms-calculator:'); ?><span class="line"><!---->calc.php: &lt;?php header('Location: ms-calculator:'); ?&gt;<!----></span><br>tel.php: <?php header('Location: tel:5555555551'); ?><span class="line"><!---->tel.php: &lt;?php header('Location: tel:5555555551'); ?&gt;<!----></span><br><br>CREDIT INFORMATION<b class="line"><!---->CREDIT INFORMATION<!----></b><br>Reporter credit: Alesandro Ortiz <<span class="line"><!---->Reporter credit: Alesandro Ortiz &lt;<!----></span>https://AlesandroOrtiz.com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://AlesandroOrtiz.com"><!---->https://AlesandroOrtiz.com<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Thanks for the report and the great demo videos, particularly that last one :-)<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the report and the great demo videos, particularly that last one :-)<!----></span><br><br>meacer@ can you take a look a this one? Adding other c/b/external_protocol/OWNERS as well.<span class="line"><!---->meacer@ can you take a look a this one? Adding other c/b/external_protocol/OWNERS as well.<!----></span><br><br>That this (1) shows the wrong origin in the dialog, but also (2) applies the wrong permissions/content settings makes this particularly nasty. I'm tentatively setting this to Sev-Medium (because it isn't quite "full circumvention of the same origin policy" or "complete control over the apparent origin in the omnibox" for Sev-High, but it kind of feels close).<span class="line"><!---->That this (1) shows the wrong origin in the dialog, but also (2) applies the wrong permissions/content settings makes this particularly nasty. I'm tentatively setting this to Sev-Medium (because it isn't quite "full circumvention of the same origin policy" or "complete control over the apparent origin in the omnibox" for Sev-High, but it kind of feels close).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        This also repros in Chromium-based Edge.<span class="line"><!---->This also repros in Chromium-based Edge.<!----></span><br><br>1. Can someone determine (or guess) if fixing in Chromium would also fix in Edge?<span class="line"><!---->1. Can someone determine (or guess) if fixing in Chromium would also fix in Edge?<!----></span><br>2. Is it okay if I also report to Microsoft with context that it also affects Chromium?<span class="line"><!---->2. Is it okay if I also report to Microsoft with context that it also affects Chromium?<!----></span><br><br>Their security program states "Vulnerabilities that reproduce in Chrome at the time of submission" are out of scope (source: <span class="line"><!---->Their security program states "Vulnerabilities that reproduce in Chrome at the time of submission" are out of scope (source: <!----></span>https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/msrc/bounty-new-edge<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/msrc/bounty-new-edge"><!---->https://www.microsoft.com/en-us/msrc/bounty-new-edge<!----></a> ), so answer to first question would help determine whether MSRC report would be eligible or not (and help them get a jump start on separate fix).<span class="line"><!----> ), so answer to first question would help determine whether MSRC report would be eligible or not (and help them get a jump start on separate fix).<!----></span><br><br>(I may delete this comment prior to crbug disclosure.)<span class="line"><!---->(I may delete this comment prior to crbug disclosure.)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        by

        I'll let external protocol OWNERS weigh in as well, but I'd assume that fixing this in Chromium will also fix this in Edge, as I've seen other external protocol handler bugs also affect Edge and I don't think they customize it much if at all downstream. In general for bug reports that affect multiple vendors, we're okay with you sending reports to each affected vendor though, but it's good for us to know if you do in case we need to coordinate disclosure.<span class="line"><!---->I'll let external protocol OWNERS weigh in as well, but I'd assume that fixing this in Chromium will also fix this in Edge, as I've seen other external protocol handler bugs also affect Edge and I don't think they customize it much if at all downstream.         To expand on my <span class="line"><!---->To expand on my <!----></span>comment #7<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c7"><!---->comment #7<!----></a>, what I'm wondering is whether navigating to a URL which performs an immediate server-side redirect to an external protocol is effectively the same as the original site having a link directly embedding that external protocol. I could see that being regarded as true, which would mean this is working as intended.<span class="line"><!---->, what I'm wondering is whether navigating to a URL which performs an immediate server-side redirect to an external protocol is effectively the same as the original site having a link directly embedding that external protocol.         by

      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1197889#c12">Comment 12<!----></a>

          
        by
        <mr-user-link></mr-user-link>
        on
        <chops-timestamp title="Wed, Apr 14, 2021, 9:14 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>
        
      
        </div>
        
      </div>
    
      
        
        
      
        To clarify my comment, HTTP Auth *does* seem to commit navigation. What I meant was that external protocol handling seems similar to HTTP Auth in terms of behavior trigger (response header controls behavior) and user flow (sensitive dialog with origin info), therefore external protocol handling probably should look more like HTTP Auth flow which commits and shows origin of dialog initiator (server sending the triggering response headers).<span class="line"><!---->To clarify my comment, HTTP Auth *does* seem to commit navigation. What I meant was that external protocol handling seems similar to HTTP Auth in terms of behavior trigger (response header controls behavior) and user flow (sensitive dialog with origin info), therefore external protocol handling probably should look more like HTTP Auth flow which commits and shows origin of dialog initiator (server sending the triggering response headers).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>
      <div class="comment-body">
        <mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        <div>
          
        </div>

        <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Apr 15, 2021, 4:34 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>

      <div role="heading" class="comment-header" aria-level="2">
        <div>
          <a class="comment-link" href="?id=1197889#c13">Comment 13<!----></a>

          
        by

        <chops-timestamp title="Thu, Apr 15, 2021, 4:34 PM EDT"></chops-timestamp>

        This looks like a variant of <span class="line"><!---->This looks like a variant of <!----></span>bug 1091961<span class="line"><!---->bug 1091961<!----></span>: The navigation doesn't update content area but ends up showing some non-content area dialog, causing a mismatch between the omnibox and the dialog.<span class="line"><!---->: The navigation doesn't update content area but ends up showing some non-content area dialog, causing a mismatch between the omnibox and the dialog.<!----></span><br><br>We have many of these. Basically, anytime a navigation results in a UI (dialog, download shelf, external app opening etc) that doesn't update the omnibox, we'll have this issue. The similarity to the HTTP auth case is a great observation, and we might need to do something similar here as well.<span class="line"><!---->We have many of these. Basically, anytime a navigation results in a UI (dialog, download shelf, external app opening etc) that doesn't update the omnibox, we'll have this issue. The similarity to the HTTP auth case is a great observation, and we might need to do something similar here as well.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
        
          
        <div>
          
        </div>

        Thanks for context. Don't have access to crbug with impact details of variants in other features, but for this feature, impact seems particularly dangerous beyond origin spoof in dialog:<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for context. Don't have access to crbug with impact details of variants in other features, but for this feature, impact seems particularly dangerous beyond origin spoof in dialog:<!----></span><br><br>1. An open redirect in an allowlisted origin can launch the protocol with zero interaction<span class="line"><!---->1. An open redirect in an allowlisted origin can launch the protocol with zero interaction<!----></span><br>e.g. Video conferencing site has open redirect + large % of userbase has origin+protocol allowlisted due to frequent use/enterprise policy + app has RCE vuln or other vuln via protocol handler<span class="line"><!---->e.g. Video conferencing site has open redirect + large % of userbase has origin+protocol allowlisted due to frequent use/enterprise policy + app has RCE vuln or other vuln via protocol handler<!----></span><br><br>2. Reasonably sandboxed iframe embedded by allowlisted origin can launch the protocol with zero interaction<span class="line"><!---->2. Reasonably sandboxed iframe embedded by allowlisted origin can launch the protocol with zero interaction<!----></span><br>e.g. Video conferencing site embeds 3rd party/arbitrary sandboxed iframe + user/enterprise has origin+protocol allowlisted + app has vuln via protocol handler<span class="line"><!---->e.g. Video conferencing site embeds 3rd party/arbitrary sandboxed iframe + user/enterprise has origin+protocol allowlisted + app has vuln via protocol handler<!----></span><br><br>3. Any link within allowlisted origin can launch protocol if clicked<span class="line"><!---->3. Any link within allowlisted origin can launch protocol if clicked<!----></span><br>e.g. Video conferencing site allows user-controlled HTTPS links in event descriptions, profile info, etc. + user/enterprise has origin+protocol allowlisted + app has vuln via protocol handler<span class="line"><!---->e.g. Video conferencing site allows user-controlled HTTPS links in event descriptions, profile info, etc. + user/enterprise has origin+protocol allowlisted + app has vuln via protocol handler<!----></span><br><br>If not allowlisted, only a single click in dialog is needed and it appears to be from the user-trusted website, so it's likely to be effective. There's also very few (if any) mitigations that I could find: CSP and sandboxing are largely ineffective; most websites with some type of user content allow user-controlled HTTPS links; combined with <span class="line"><!---->If not allowlisted, only a single click in dialog is needed and it appears to be from the user-trusted website, so it's likely to be effective. There's also very few (if any) mitigations that I could find: CSP and sandboxing are largely ineffective; most websites with some type of user content allow user-controlled HTTPS links; combined with <!----></span>issue 1196495<span class="line"><!---->issue 1196495<!----></span> and<span class="line"><!----> and<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>issue 1096610<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1096610" title="External Protocol handler anti-flood protection is ineffective and flaky"><!---->issue 1096610<!----></a> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>behaviors, it's easy to bypass protocol launch user interaction requirements for many users.<span class="line"><!---->behaviors, it's easy to bypass protocol launch user interaction requirements for many users.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Sorry for the delay.  Let me try to answer some of the questions above (and also add the UI>Browser>Navigation component for more people to take a look).<span class="line"><!---->Sorry for the delay.  Let me try to answer some of the questions above (and also add the UI&gt;Browser&gt;Navigation component for more people to take a look).<!----></span><br><br>RE: external protocol handling probably should look more like HTTP Auth flow which commits<span class="line"><!---->RE: external protocol handling probably should look more like HTTP Auth flow which commits<!----></span><br><br>A navigation "commits", when a frame (e.g. content::RenderFrameImpl) will host a document.  External protocol handler doesn't create/commit a new document in a frames.<span class="line"><!---->A navigation "commits", when a frame (e.g. content::RenderFrameImpl) will host a document.  External protocol handler doesn't create/commit a new document in a frames.<!----></span><br><br>RE: External protocols in server-side redirects probably should be treated similarly to javascript: URLs in server-side redirects, which are blocked by the browser as unsafe.<span class="line"><!---->RE: External protocols in server-side redirects probably should be treated similarly to javascript: URLs in server-side redirects, which are blocked by the browser as unsafe.<!----></span><br><br>Agreed.  AFAIK we already block HTTP -> chrome-extension:// and HTTP -> file:// redirects, so this seems like definitive bug.  Let me open a separate bug for this in <span class="line"><!---->Agreed.  AFAIK we already block HTTP -&gt; chrome-extension:// and HTTP -&gt; file:// redirects, so this seems like definitive bug.  Let me open a separate bug for this in <!----></span>issue 1203814<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1203814" title="Consider blocking HTTP -> externally-handled-protocol redirects "><!---->issue 1203814<!----></a>.<span class="line"><!---->.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        Re: <span class="line"><!---->Re: <!----></span>#c19<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c19"><!---->#c19<!----></a>, that's correct, passing origin of last redirecting server should take care of dialog origin spoof in all reported scenarios.<span class="line"><!---->, that's correct, passing origin of last redirecting server should take care of dialog origin spoof in all reported scenarios.<!----></span><br><br>There's still other apparent issues, such as sandbox + CSP bypass and omnibox mismatch, but those would be moot if server-side redirect is blocked altogether (thanks for filing spinoff <span class="line"><!---->There's still other apparent issues, such as sandbox + CSP bypass and omnibox mismatch, but those would be moot if server-side redirect is blocked altogether (thanks for filing spinoff <!----></span>issue 1203814<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1203814" title="Consider blocking HTTP -> externally-handled-protocol redirects "><!---->issue 1203814<!----></a>).<span class="line"><!---->).<!----></span><br><br>> <span class="line"><!---->&gt; <!----></span>#c19<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c19"><!---->#c19<!----></a>: I would expect the correct origin to be shown in the dialog here [here = in absence of http redirects]).<span class="line"><!---->: I would expect the correct origin to be shown in the dialog here [here = in absence of http redirects]).<!----></span><br><br>Yes, current behavior is safe for direct navigation scenarios (e.g. <a href="ms-calculator:">calc</a> or window.location = 'ms-calculator:'). The current page's origin is shown as expected. I would expect direct navigation to still be allowed, since untrusted non-HTTPS URLs can and should be blocked by websites, much like they often block direct javascript: URLs in anchor href, window.location, window.open, iframe src, etc.<span class="line"><!---->Yes, current behavior is safe for direct navigation scenarios (e.g. &lt;a href="ms-calculator:"&gt;calc&lt;/a&gt; or window.location = 'ms-calculator:'). The current page's origin is shown as expected. I would expect direct navigation to still be allowed, since untrusted non-HTTPS URLs can and should be blocked by websites, much like they often block direct javascript: URLs in anchor href, window.location, window.open, iframe src, etc.<!----></span><br><br>Scenario 2 is for window.location navigation to a URL which returns a server-side redirect. Under the hood it's essentially the same behavior, but wanted to make it clear this repros with other common places where untrusted URLs are accepted by websites. (For reference, Scenario 2 PoC: <span class="line"><!---->Scenario 2 is for window.location navigation to a URL which returns a server-side redirect. Under the hood it's essentially the same behavior, but wanted to make it clear this repros with other common places where untrusted URLs are accepted by websites. (For reference, Scenario 2 PoC: <!----></span>https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Faogarantiza.com%2Fchromium%2Fexternal-protocol%2Fcalc.php&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AFQjCNGOqAoEa7AghaevcuD3T2XmJY62gw<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Faogarantiza.com%2Fchromium%2Fexternal-protocol%2Fcalc.php&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNGOqAoEa7AghaevcuD3T2XmJY62gw"><!---->https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Faogarantiza.com%2Fchromium%2Fexternal-protocol%2Fcalc.php&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNGOqAoEa7AghaevcuD3T2XmJY62gw<!----></a> )<span class="line"><!----> )<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        The following revision refers to this bug:<span class="line"><!---->The following revision refers to this bug:<!----></span><br>  <span class="line"><!---->  <!----></span>https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/f781748dcb3c7d0420b884c1c24b9b4497bc7c97<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/f781748dcb3c7d0420b884c1c24b9b4497bc7c97"><!---->https://chromium.googlesource.com/chromium/src/+/f781748dcb3c7d0420b884c1c24b9b4497bc7c97<!----></a><br><br>commit <span class="line"><!---->commit <!----></span>f781748dcb3c7d0420b884c1c24b9b4497bc7c97<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://crrev.com/f781748dcb3c7d0420b884c1c24b9b4497bc7c97"><!---->f781748dcb3c7d0420b884c1c24b9b4497bc7c97<!----></a><br>Author: Ravjit <<span class="line"><!---->Author: Ravjit &lt;<!----></span>ravjit@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="/u/ravjit@chromium.org"><!---->ravjit@chromium.org<!----></a>><span class="line"><!---->&gt;<!----></span><br>Date: Thu Sep 16 12:29:55 2021<span class="line"><!---->Date: Thu Sep 16 12:29:55 2021<!----></span><br><br>Show the origin of the last redirecting server in external protocol handler dialogs<span class="line"><!---->Show the origin of the last redirecting server in external protocol handler dialogs<!----></span><br><br>External protocol handlers always show the initiating url's origin. This can be misleading if there are server side redirects.<span class="line"><!---->External protocol handlers always show the initiating url's origin. This can be misleading if there are server side redirects.<!----></span><br>Now we will show the origin of the last redirecting server (falling back to the request_initiator if there were no redirects / if the request goes straight to an external protocol).<span class="line"><!---->Now we will show the origin of the last redirecting server (falling back to the request_initiator if there were no redirects / if the request goes straight to an external protocol).<!----></span><br><br>Bug: 1197889<a class="strike-through" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1197889"         *** Boilerplate reminders! ***<span class="line"><!---->*** Boilerplate reminders! ***<!----></span><br>Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<span class="line"><!---->Please do NOT publicly disclose details until a fix has been released to all our users. Early public disclosure may cancel the provisional reward. Also, please be considerate about disclosure when the bug affects a core library that may be used by other products. Please do NOT share this information with third parties who are not directly involved in fixing the bug. Doing so may cancel the provisional reward. Please be honest if you have already disclosed anything publicly or to third parties. Lastly, we understand that some of you are not interested in money. We offer the option to donate your reward to an eligible charity. If you prefer this option, let us know and we will also match your donation - subject to our discretion. Any rewards that are unclaimed after 12 months will be donated to a charity of our choosing.<!----></span><br><br>Please contact <span class="line"><!---->Please contact <!----></span>security-vrp@chromium.org<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="mailto:security-vrp@chromium.org"><!---->security-vrp@chromium.org<!----></a> with any questions.<span class="line"><!----> with any questions.<!----></span><br>******************************<span class="line"><!---->******************************<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

            Issue 1197889: Security: Origin spoof in external protocol dialogs via server-side redirect to external protocol
          <h1>
            
            Issue 1197889: Security: Origin spoof in external protocol dialogs via server-side redirect to external protocol
          </h1>
          
            Reported by
            
      <link href="https://fonts.googleapis.com/icon?family=Material+Icons" rel="stylesheet">
      schedule<i id="availability-icon" class="material-icons inline-icon ${user.last_visit_timestamp ? '': 'inline-icon-unseen'}" title="undefined" hidden="">schedule</i>

        Description #1 by alesa...@alesandroortiz.com (Apr 10, 2021)
      <option value="0" selected="">

      <div class="select-container">
        <select aria-label="Description history menu" hidden="">

      <option value="0" selected="">
        Description #1 by alesa...@alesandroortiz.com (Apr 10, 2021)

    <!---->
        </select>
      </div>
      VULNERABILITY DETAILS<b class="line"><!---->VULNERABILITY DETAILS<!----></b><br>A URL responding with a server-side redirect to an external protocol can trigger an external protocol dialog with a spoofed origin. The origin is never the redirecting URL's origin. Instead, the initiating page's origin (or precursor origin if opaque) is shown in dialogs. This affects both application protocols (e.g. ms-calculator:) and the telephone protocol (tel:). The UI for these are different, but the effects are similar in most cases.<span class="line"><!---->A URL responding with a server-side redirect to an external protocol can trigger an external protocol dialog with a spoofed origin. The origin is never the redirecting URL's origin. Instead, the initiating page's origin (or precursor origin if opaque) is shown in dialogs. This affects both application protocols (e.g. ms-calculator:) and the telephone protocol (tel:). The UI for these are different, but the effects are similar in most cases.<!----></span><br><br>For example, if a page on <span class="line"><!---->For example, if a page on <!----></span>https://www.google[.]com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.google[.]com"><!---->https://www.google[.]com<!----></a> contains a link (<a href="...">) to <span class="line"><!----> contains a link (&lt;a href="..."&gt;) to <!----></span>https://attacker[.]tld/redirect<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://attacker[.]tld/redirect"><!---->https://attacker[.]tld/redirect<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> and a user clicks the link, the dialog will show <span class="line"><!----> and a user clicks the link, the dialog will show <!----></span>https://www.google[.]com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.google[.]com"><!---->https://www.google[.]com<!----></a> as the origin instead of <span class="line"><!----> as the origin instead of <!----></span>https://attacker[.]tld<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://attacker[.]tld"><!---->https://attacker[.]tld<!----></a> .<span class="line"><!----> .<!----></span><br><br>Similarly, if a page on <span class="line"><!---->Similarly, if a page on <!----></span>https://www.google[.]com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.google[.]com"><!---->https://www.google[.]com<!----></a> navigates the current window or new window via JavaScript (window.location or window.open()) to <span class="line"><!----> navigates the current window or new window via JavaScript (window.location or window.open()) to <!----></span>https://attacker[.]tld/redirect<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://attacker[.]tld/redirect"><!---->https://attacker[.]tld/redirect<!----></a>,<span class="line"><!---->,<!----></span> the dialog will show <span class="line"><!----> the dialog will show <!----></span>https://www.google[.]com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.google[.]com"><!---->https://www.google[.]com<!----></a> as the origin.<span class="line"><!----> as the origin.<!----></span><br><br>In effect, the behavior is the same as if the page had directly used the external protocol URL (ms-calculator:) instead of the HTTPS URL (<span class="line"><!---->In effect, the behavior is the same as if the page had directly used the external protocol URL (ms-calculator:) instead of the HTTPS URL (<!----></span>https://attacker[.]tld/redirect<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://attacker[.]tld/redirect"><!---->https://attacker[.]tld/redirect<!----></a>).<span class="line"><!---->).<!----></span><br><br>As far as I can tell, common protections such as CSP and iframe sandboxing are bypassed in most scenarios.<span class="line"><!---->As far as I can tell, common protections such as CSP and iframe sandboxing are bypassed in most scenarios.<!----></span><br><br>No user interaction is needed if a user previously checked "Always allow {origin} to open links of this type..." for the target origin and protocol, or if allowed for origin+protocol via enterprise policy: <span class="line"><!---->No user interaction is needed if a user previously checked "Always allow {origin} to open links of this type..." for the target origin and protocol, or if allowed for origin+protocol via enterprise policy: <!----></span>https://chromeenterprise.google/policies/#AutoLaunchProtocolsFromOrigins<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://chromeenterprise.google/policies/#AutoLaunchProtocolsFromOrigins"><!---->https://chromeenterprise.google/policies/#AutoLaunchProtocolsFromOrigins<!----></a><br><br>ADDITIONAL INFO<span class="line"><!---->ADDITIONAL INFO<!----></span><br>A malicious URL could be placed in search result pages, "external link" interstitial pages, user-provided URLs in content, among many other scenarios. Most websites filter input to only allow http(s) URLs (generally to avoid javascript: URLs which are blocked by browser in server-side redirects), therefore this works as an effective bypass to spoof the origin across most websites and navigation methods.<span class="line"><!---->A malicious URL could be placed in search result pages, "external link" interstitial pages, user-provided URLs in content, among many other scenarios. Most websites filter input to only allow http(s) URLs (generally to avoid javascript: URLs which are blocked by browser in server-side redirects), therefore this works as an effective bypass to spoof the origin across most websites and navigation methods.<!----></span><br><br>See attached video spoof-google-search.mp4 for Google Search demo with both calc and tel PoCs. Note that I only enabled this PoC to work from my IP address for a few minutes to record the video.<span class="line"><!---->See attached video spoof-google-search.mp4 for Google Search demo with both calc and tel PoCs. Note that I only enabled this PoC to work from my IP address for a few minutes to record the video.<!----></span><br><br>External protocols in server-side redirects probably should be treated similarly to javascript: URLs in server-side redirects, which are blocked by the browser as unsafe. Otherwise, the browser could render a blank page with origin set to the server-side redirect initiator, to ensure the dialog and address bar show the correct origin and the tab doesn't have another origin's content rendered.<span class="line"><!---->External protocols in server-side redirects probably should be treated similarly to javascript: URLs in server-side redirects, which are blocked by the browser as unsafe. Otherwise, the browser could render a blank page with origin set to the server-side redirect initiator, to ensure the dialog and address bar show the correct origin and the tab doesn't have another origin's content rendered.<!----></span><br><br>Some of the PoCs benefit from behaviors described in <span class="line"><!---->Some of the PoCs benefit from behaviors described in <!----></span>issue 1196495<span class="line"><!---->issue 1196495<!----></span> and<span class="line"><!----> and<!----></span> <span class="line"><!----> <!----></span>issue 1096610<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=1096610" title="External Protocol handler anti-flood protection is ineffective and flaky"><!---->issue 1096610<!----></a>, <span class="line"><!---->, <!----></span>but are not dependent on them for success.<span class="line"><!---->but are not dependent on them for success.<!----></span><br><br>VERSION<b class="line"><!---->VERSION<!----></b><br>Chrome Version: 89.0.4389.114 (Official Build) (64-bit) (cohort: Stable), also repros on 91.0.4468.0 Canary<span class="line"><!---->Chrome Version: 89.0.4389.114 (Official Build) (64-bit) (cohort: Stable), also repros on 91.0.4468.0 Canary<!----></span><br>Operating System: Windows 10 OS Version 2009 (Build 19042.867)<span class="line"><!---->Operating System: Windows 10 OS Version 2009 (Build 19042.867)<!----></span><br><br>REPRODUCTION CASE<b class="line"><!---->REPRODUCTION CASE<!----></b><br>Scenario 1: Link click<span class="line"><!---->Scenario 1: Link click<!----></span><br>1. Navigate to <span class="line"><!---->1. Navigate to <!----></span>https://alesandroortiz.com/security/chromium/external-protocol/spoof-links.html<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://alesandroortiz.com/security/chromium/external-protocol/spoof-links.html"><!---->https://alesandroortiz.com/security/chromium/external-protocol/spoof-links.html<!----></a><br>2. Click either of the links<span class="line"><!---->2. Click either of the links<!----></span><br><br>Observed: External protocol dialog shown with current page origin (<span class="line"><!---->Observed: External protocol dialog shown with current page origin (<!----></span>https://alesandroortiz[.]com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://alesandroortiz[.]com"><!---->https://alesandroortiz[.]com<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><br>Expected: External protocol dialog is not shown or is shown with redirecting origin (<span class="line"><!---->Expected: External protocol dialog is not shown or is shown with redirecting origin (<!----></span>https://aogarantiza[.]com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://aogarantiza[.]com"><!---->https://aogarantiza[.]com<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><br><br>Scenario 2: JavaScript redirect (window.location)<span class="line"><!---->Scenario 2: JavaScript redirect (window.location)<!----></span><br>1. Navigate to one of these URLs:<span class="line"><!---->1. Navigate to one of these URLs:<!----></span><br>https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Faogarantiza.com%2Fchromium%2Fexternal-protocol%2Fcalc.php&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AFQjCNGOqAoEa7AghaevcuD3T2XmJY62gw<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Faogarantiza.com%2Fchromium%2Fexternal-protocol%2Fcalc.php&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNGOqAoEa7AghaevcuD3T2XmJY62gw"><!---->https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Faogarantiza.com%2Fchromium%2Fexternal-protocol%2Fcalc.php&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNGOqAoEa7AghaevcuD3T2XmJY62gw<!----></a><br>https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Faogarantiza.com%2Fchromium%2Fexternal-protocol%2Ftel.php&sa=D&sntz=1&usg=AFQjCNEUEKsWLeTxzL6gKZT1TR_zarnCJg<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Faogarantiza.com%2Fchromium%2Fexternal-protocol%2Ftel.php&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNEUEKsWLeTxzL6gKZT1TR_zarnCJg"><!---->https://www.google.com/url?q=https%3A%2F%2Faogarantiza.com%2Fchromium%2Fexternal-protocol%2Ftel.php&amp;sa=D&amp;sntz=1&amp;usg=AFQjCNEUEKsWLeTxzL6gKZT1TR_zarnCJg<!----></a><br><br>Observed: Dialog shown with correct origin.<span class="line"><!---->Observed: Dialog shown with correct origin.<!----></span><br>Expected: Dialog shown with spoofed origin.<span class="line"><!---->Expected: Dialog shown with spoofed origin.<!----></span><br><br>Scenario 3: Page has iframe with user-controlled src to URL responding with server-side redirect<span class="line"><!---->Scenario 3: Page has iframe with user-controlled src to URL responding with server-side redirect<!----></span><br>1. Navigate to <span class="line"><!---->1. Observe onload PoC of second iframe, then click link in first iframe<!----></span><br><br>Observed: Dialog shown with embedding page origin (<span class="line"><!---->Observed: Dialog shown with embedding page origin (<!----></span>https://alesandroortiz[.]com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://alesandroortiz[.]com"><!---->https://alesandroortiz[.]com<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><br>Expected: Dialog shown with iframe src origin (<span class="line"><!---->Expected: Dialog shown with iframe src origin (<!----></span>https://aogarantiza[.]com<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://aogarantiza[.]com"><!---->https://aogarantiza[.]com<!----></a>)<span class="line"><!---->)<!----></span><br><br>Scenario 5: Attacker page with refreshing iframe with client-side redirect leading to server-side redirect<span class="line"><!---->Scenario 5: Attacker page with refreshing iframe with client-side redirect leading to server-side redirect<!----></span><br>1. Navigate to <span class="line"><!---->1. With most extensions, prompt will be reshown without further user interactions (<span class="line"><!---->2. With most extensions, prompt will be reshown without further user interactions (<!----></span>issue 173557<a class="" target="_blank" href="/p/chromium/issues/detail?id=173557" title="Security: Extensions can enable websites to carpet bomb with external protocol dialogs"><!---->issue 173557<!----></a>). Otherwise, interact with any page or browser UI to show prompt.<span class="line"><!---->). Otherwise, interact with any page or browser UI to show prompt.<!----></span><br><br>Observed: Dialog shown with embedding page origin (<span class="line"><!---->Observed: Dialog shown with embedding         Thanks for the report and the great demo videos, particularly that last one :-)<span class="line"><!---->Thanks for the report and the great demo videos, particularly that last one :-)<!----></span><br><br>meacer@ can you take a look a this one? Adding other c/b/external_protocol/OWNERS as well.<span class="line"><!---->meacer@ can you take a look a this one? Adding other c/b/external_protocol/OWNERS as well.<!----></span><br><br>That this (1) shows the wrong origin in the dialog, but also (2) applies the wrong permissions/content settings makes this particularly nasty. I'm tentatively setting this to Sev-Medium (because it isn't quite "full circumvention of the same origin policy" or "complete control over the apparent origin in the omnibox" for Sev-High, but it kind of feels close).<span class="line"><!---->That this (1) shows the wrong origin in the dialog, but also (2) applies the wrong permissions/content settings makes this particularly nasty. I'm tentatively setting this to Sev-Medium (because it isn't quite "full circumvention of the same origin policy" or "complete control over the apparent origin in the omnibox" for Sev-High, but it kind of feels close).<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        by

        I'll let external protocol OWNERS weigh in as well, but I'd assume that fixing this in Chromium will also fix this in Edge, as I've seen other external protocol handler bugs also affect Edge and I don't think they customize it much if at all downstream. In general for bug reports that affect multiple vendors, we're okay with you sending reports to each affected vendor though, but it's good for us to know if you do in case we need to coordinate disclosure.<span class="line"><!---->I'll let external protocol OWNERS weigh in as well, but I'd assume that fixing this in Chromium will also fix this in Edge, as I've seen other external protocol handler bugs also affect Edge and I don't think they customize it much if at all downstream. In general for bug reports that affect multiple vendors, we're okay with you sending reports to each affected vendor though, but it's good for us to know if you do in case we need to coordinate disclosure.<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        I would also guess that fixing this in Chromium would fix it in Edge.<span class="line"><!---->I would also guess that fixing this in Chromium would fix it in Edge.<!----></span><br><br>This is pretty interesting. In the former, we pass what eventually ends up in the dialog as ResourceRequest::request_initiator:<span class="line"><!---->This is pretty interesting.         To expand on my <span class="line"><!---->To expand on my <!----></span>comment #7<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c7"><!---->comment #7<!----></a>, what I'm wondering is whether navigating to a URL which performs an immediate server-side redirect to an external protocol is effectively the same as the original site having a link directly embedding that external protocol. I could see that being regarded as true, which would mean this is working as intended.<span class="line"><!---->, what I'm wondering is whether navigating to a URL which performs an immediate server-side redirect to an external protocol is effectively the same as the original site having a link directly embedding that external protocol. I could see that being regarded as true, which would mean this is working as intended.<!----></span><br><br>For instance, directly navigating to <span class="line"><!---->For instance, directly navigating to <!----></span>https://aogarantiza.com/chromium/external-protocol/calc.php<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="https://aogarantiza.com/chromium/external-protocol/calc.php"><!---->https://aogarantiza.com/chromium/external-protocol/calc.php<!----></a> shows nothing in the omnibox, which suggests to me that no actual navigation is being committed, and all we've exchanged with the site is headers. That being said, we've exchanged at least headers with the second origin, but I don't know enough about the innards of navigation to say what we should do in this case :)<span class="line"><!----> shows nothing in the omnibox, which suggests to me that no actual navigation is being committed, and all we've exchanged with the site is headers. That being said, we've exchanged at least headers with the second origin, but I don't know enough about the innards of navigation to say what we should do in this case :)<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>

        > This also seems close to a cross-origin HTTP Auth dialog scenario. When an HTTP Auth dialog is shown due to a cross-origin navigation, a blank page is rendered and the omnibox shows the dialog-initiating URL.<span class="line"><!---->&gt; This also seems close to a cross-origin HTTP Auth dialog scenario. When an HTTP Auth dialog is shown due to a cross-origin navigation, a blank page is rendered and the omnibox shows the dialog-initiating URL.<!----></span><br><br>Interesting observation - that seems to match the behaviour we see here where there's no committed navigation and the request initiator is still regarded as the initial origin that was navigated from.<span class="line"><!---->Interesting observation - that seems to match the behaviour we see here where there's no committed navigation and the request initiator is still regarded as the initial origin that was navigated from.<!----></span><br><br>We possibly need some navigation experts on this. +lukasza and +alexmos, can you weigh in on my questions in <span class="line"><!---->We possibly need some navigation experts on this. +lukasza and +alexmos, can you weigh in on my questions in <!----></span>comment#7<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c7"><!---->comment#7<!----></a> and <span class="line"><!----> and <!----></span>comment#8<a class="undefined" target="_blank" href="#c8"><!---->comment#8<!----></a>?<span class="line"><!---->?<!----></span><mr-comment-content></mr-comment-content>
